user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueueGetIdByName:
```c
int32 OS_QueueGetIdByName(osal_id_t *queue_id, const char *queue_name)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(queue_id);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(queue_name);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindByName(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, queue_name, queue_id);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_QueueGetIdByName:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
void OS_printf(const char *String, ...)
{
    va_list va;
    char    msg_buffer[OS_BUFFER_SIZE];
    int     actualsz;

    BUGCHECK_VOID(String != NULL)

    if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_INIT_MAGIC_NUMBER)
    {
        /*
         * Catch some historical mis-use of the OS_printf() call.
         *
         * Typically OS_printf() should NOT be called before OS_API_Init().
         *
         * This was never guaranteed to work, particularly on a VxWorks
         * deployment where the utility task was enabled.
         *
         * However, some PSPs do this, particularly those that used POSIX
         * where it happened to work (because OS_printf just called printf).
         *
         * As a workaround, use the OS_DEBUG facility to dump the message,
         * along with a clue that this API is being used inappropriately.
         *
         * If debugging is not enabled, then this message will be silently
         * discarded.
         */
        OS_DEBUG("BUG: OS_printf() called when OSAL not initialized: %s", String);
    }
    else if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.PrintfEnabled)
    {
        /* Format and determine the size of string to write */
        va_start(va, String);
        actualsz = vsnprintf(msg_buffer, sizeof(msg_buffer), String, va);
        va_end(va);

        if (actualsz < 0)
        {
            /* unlikely: vsnprintf failed */
            actualsz = 0;
        }
        else if (actualsz >= OS_BUFFER_SIZE)
        {
            /* truncate */
            actualsz = OS_BUFFER_SIZE - 1;
        }

        msg_buffer[actualsz] = 0;

        OS_ConsoleWrite(OS_SharedGlobalVars.PrintfConsoleId, msg_buffer);
    }
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFindByName(osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, osal_id_t *object_id)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /*
     * As this is an internal-only function, calling it with NULL is allowed.
     * This is required by the file/dir/socket API since these DO allow multiple
     * instances of the same name.
     */
    ARGCHECK(name, OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND);
    LENGTHCHECK(name, OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, idtype, name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *object_id = token.obj_id;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No explicit compiler language extensions are present in the provided code fragments. The code uses only standard C constructs: function definitions with typed parameters, standard typedefs (int32_t-based), variadic functions with va_list/va_start/va_end and vsnprintf (all standard), macros and constant-sized buffers. Common extension markers such as GCC/Clang attributes (__attribute__), inline assembler (__asm__), statement-expressions ({ ... }), typeof, __builtin_* intrinsics, nested functions, labels-as-values, or other compiler-specific tokens do not appear in the shown code.

Notes on items examined but not reported:
- Macros such as OS_CHECK_POINTER, BUGCHECK, BUGCHECK_VOID, ARGCHECK, LENGTHCHECK, and OS_ObjectIdGetByName/OS_ConsoleWrite call sites could potentially expand to compiler-specific extensions, but their definitions are not provided here (only some macro uses were shown). Per the rule guidance you requested, I report only explicit uses of language extensions visible in the source. Since the macro expansions are not shown, they cannot be flagged as using extensions based on the provided text.
- The typedefs (e.g., osal_id_t based on uint32, and int32 based on int32_t) are ordinary typedefs; the names themselves are not compiler extensions.
- Use of ellipsis (...) in the OS_printf prototype/definition denotes a standard C variadic function, not a compiler extension.

If you can provide the actual definitions/expansions of the macros (BUGCHECK, BUGCHECK_VOID, OS_CHECK_POINTER, ARGCHECK, LENGTHCHECK) or any compiler-specific header contents, I can re-evaluate those expansions for hidden compiler extensions. Based on the code shown, there are no visible language-extension usages to report.
